div1.p: This document describes Carroll's various postings, beginning in September 1883, and includes evaluations of his performance by several commanding officers. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Report: Military History of Hospital Steward James Carroll, U.S. Army, [October, 1907]
div1.p:
OFFICE SURG. GENL.
PERSONNEL DIV'N,
OCT 4 1907
HOSPITAL CORPS.

Military history of Hospital Steward James Carroll, U.S. Army.
appointed hospital steward, U.S. Army, September 15, 1883, from sergeant
Company “C” 7th U.S. Infantry. (He enlisted first in Company “E”
1st U.S. Infantry, January 9, 1874, was discharged from it Jany. 9, 1879,
reenlisted in Company “C” 7th U.S. Infantry, January 22, 1879.) Upon
appointment as hospital steward he was ordered to proceed from Fort
Douglas, Utah to Fort Snelling, Minn., where he arrived October 2, 1883;
was ordered thence to Fort Custer, Mt., where he arrived Oct. 10, 1883,
and reported for duty to the commanding officer; while at that post
he was discharged per expiration of term January 21, 1884, and re-
enlisted January 22, 1884. Assistant Surgeon C. E. Price the post
surgeon, in reporting the discharge and reenlistment said of Carroll
that “He is a faithful, efficient, reliable steward, strictly temper-
ate and of excellent character”. On May 24, 1884, he accompanied
a battalion of the 2d cavalry from Fort Custer to Fort Missoula, Mt.,
and returned to Custer July 15, 1884, with a battalion of the 1st cav.,
he remained on duty at Fort Custer to August 27, 1886, when he left
for Fort Snelling, Minn., he was relieved from duty in the Department
of Dakota; assigned to the Department of the Platte by War Dept.,
orders, and granted a furlough for one month which was extended five
months with permission to go abroad. On his return from furlough
he was assigned to duty at Camp Pilot Butte, Wyoming, where he ar-
rived April 2, 1887; he was thence transferred to Ft. Omaha, Neb.,
where he reported Nov. 7, 1887. In his examination for reenlistment
Major Smart who examined the papers gave him an average of 95.6 per
cent. Steward Carroll was discharged per expiration of service
2.
January 21, 1889, and reenlisted Jany 22, 1889, character “excellent”
He was relieved from duty at Ft. Omaha and assigned to duty at
Washington Barracks, D.C., where he arrived February 14, 1889, and
thence transferred to Ft. McHenry, Md., where he arrived Feby 25, 1889.
In an inspection report concerning Ft, McHenry,Medical Director Page
reported the efficiency of Steward Carroll as follows: “Exceptionally
good in every particular”. He was relieved from duty at Ft. McHenry
in March 1893, and assigned to duty in the city of Baltimore, Md.
He remained there until April 1893, when he was assigned to duty at
the U.S. Army Hospital, Jackson Park, Chicago, Illinois, (Columbian
Exposition) He remained there until Nov. 1893, when he was assigned
to duty with the Army Medical School at Washington, D. C. where he
reported for duty Nov. 26, 1893. In reporting the efficiency of Steward
Carroll Captain LaGarde said “that his character was excellent,
efficiency and attention to duty excellent, very faithful to his
duties, a good disciplinarian and property steward and by far one of
the most capable hospital stewards in the U.S. Army.” He remained on
duty at the Army Medical School until discharged May 21, 1898, in com-
pliance with War Department orders. While on duty at the Army
Medical Museum, Surgeon Reed reported that Carroll in the line of
duty accidentally wounded himself during the dissection of a rabbit
inoculated with hydrophobia. In reporting the result of the re-
examination of Steward Carroll for reenlistment Major Smart said as
follows: “Steward Carroll's papers are models of conciseness and
accuracy. They show him to have an excellent practical knowledge of
his subjects.
